name: Clean and disinfect wound
des: Clean the wound daily with mild soap and water.

name: Change bandages or dressings
des: Change bandages regularly. Change especially if it gets wet, dirty, or starts to smell.

name: Put on medicated cream
des: Put on medicated cream as reccommended by doctor.

name: Follow up with primary care physician
Get stitches or staples removed
des: Have your stitches or staples removed as told by your doctor.

name: Wash hands regularly
des: Refer to Info page.

name: Ensure you have all the supplies for wound care
des: Antibacterial solution, Sterile gloves, Bandage, Tape, Cotton swabs or Q-tips, a small plastic bag, Antibiotic ointment.

name: Add all medications
des:
Avoid medicine containing aspirin or anti-inflammatory medications, such as ibuprofen (Motrin, Advil), Naprosyn, etc. You may use acetaminophen (Tylenol) or the medicine 
your doctor has recommended for mild pain. Keep a current list of your medicines: Include the amounts, and when, how, and why you take them.

name: Reframe from sedatives or alcholic beverages
Monitor signs and symptoms
des: If there is confusion,drowsiness,nausea,worse dizziness,convulsions,bloody discharge from nose or mouth, seek help immediately.

name: Have caregiver monitor you for 24 hours after sustaining injury
des: If there is confusion,drowsiness,nausea,worse dizziness,convulsions,bloody discharge from nose or mouth, seek help immediately.

name: Initially, eat light
des: Take clear liquids immediatly day after sustaining injury and then resume regular diet.

name: Apply Ice
des: Apply the ice for 10 to 20 minutes, 3 or more times a day. Do not apply ice directly to the skin. Place a towel over the cold pack before applying it to the skin.

name: Have caregiver wake you up during the night
des: Seek immediate medical care if the caregiver can't awake you.

name: Follow up with primary care physician
des: You should have a follow up with your primary care doctor in two weeks. Call his office the day you get home to schedule your follow up.

name: Add all medications
des: Keep a current list of your medicines: Include the amounts, and when, how, and why you take them.

name: Take antibiotics
des: Take antibiotics as told by your doctor.

name: Drink enough water and fluids to keep your urine clear or pale yellow
Get daily physical activity
des: Refer to Info page.

name: Do stress and relaxation techniques
des: Refer to Info page.

name: Do controlled breathing techniques
des: Refer to Info page.

name: Cough and clear mucus from your lungs
des: Refer to Info page.

name: Wash your hands regularly
des: Refer to Info page.

name: Follow up with primary care physician
List all current treatments or therapies
Add all medications
des: Keep a current list of your medicines: Include the amounts, and when, how, and why you take them.

name: Follow up with primary care physician
Attend a support group with others suffering from chronic pain
Set time to exercise and stretch
des: Exercise for 20 to 30 minutes, 2 to 3 times a week

name: Apply ice and heat
des: Apply the heat or ice for 10 to 20 minutes, 3 or more times a day.

name: Wiggle your fingers or toes frequently
des: This is to maintain circulation.

name: Keep your cast clean and dry
des: Keep your cast clean and dry so it doesn't come apart

name: Exercise all joints next to the injury that are not immobilized by the cast or splint.
des: For example, if you have a long leg cast, exercise the hip joint and toes. If you have an arm cast or splint, exercise the shoulder, elbow, thumb, and fingers.

name: Elevate your injured arm or leg on 1 or 2 pillows for the first 1 to 3 days to decrease swelling and pain.
des: It is best if you can comfortably elevate your cast so it is higher than your heart.

name: Check the cast daily for cracks and changes.
Keep the cast dry and clean. Wash the outside of the cast as needed.
des: Wash it with a damp cloth and mild soap. Allow the cast to air dry.

name: Wear loose clothing over the spica cast
Wear a bib or towel to cover the cast while eating
Petal" the spica cast
des: This means lining the edges of the cast with soft, smooth tape or moleskin to protect the skin. For each edge or opening:Cut 4 inch strips of tape or moleskin. Stick 1 end under the edge of the cast onto the cotton liner. Fold over the rest of the tape or moleskin, and stick it onto the outside of the cast. Continue this process by overlapping strips to make a sealed edge.

name: Put rubbing alcohol or a solution prescribed by your caregiver on the skin near the edges of the cast 2 to 3 times per day.
des: This will help toughen the skin. Stop if the skin becomes too dry or cracked.
